original: Fredriksson, Viktor Adolf, folkskolinspektör, Göteborg, f. 23/6/92 i Nå-runga, Älvsb. 1. G. 19 m. Alice Bernsten. Barn: Ulla f. 21, Margit 27, Ingrid 29. — Und:off:ex. v. Göta art:-reg. 12, folksk :lär :ex. 19, ’kurs i psykologi v. Gbgs högsk. 28. Stud:res. t. Danm., Norge, Tyskl. o. Schweiz 30- 41. Medarb. i Gbgs-Posten 13-19, anst. v. Gbgs folksk. fr. 19, ord. lär. 21, tillsyn :lär. 26, överlär. 33, folksk :-insp. i Gbgstraktens insp :omr. sed. 42. Pressomb :man i Sv. folksk :lär :förb. 25-33, styr:led. där 28-33, led. av styr. f. Sv:es aMm. folksk :lär :fören. 30-46, ordf. 45-46, Hed. av styr. f. Stretereds skolhem 30-39’, ordf. 39, led. av Gbgs barnav:nd sed. 40 o. av 40 års skol-utredn., led. av styr. f. Barnens dags-fören. 35-42, led. av kyrkofullm. sed. 36 o.-av intagn:nd v. ö. realsk. 40-41. Skr.: fackupps. i skol- o. dagspressen, red. f. Sv. folksk. historia.
translated:
Fredriksson, Viktor Adolf, elementary school inspector, Gothenburg. Born on June 23, 1892 in Nå-runga, Älvsborg County. Married once to Alice Bernsten in 19xx. They had three children: Ulla (born in 1921), Margit (born in 1927), and Ingrid (born in 1929). He passed the non-commissioned officer exam at the Göta Artillery Regiment in 1912, the elementary school teacher exam in 1919, and attended a psychology course at Gothenburg University in 1928. He went on study trips to Denmark, Norway, Germany, and Switzerland between 1930-1941. He worked as a collaborator for Goteborgs-Posten between 1913-1919 and was employed as an elementary school teacher from 1919. He became a regular teacher in 1921, a supervisor teacher in 1926, and head teacher in 1933. He served as an elementary school inspector in the Gothenburg region from 1942.

He was a press ombudsman for the Swedish National Elementary School Teachers' Association between 1925-1933 and served as a board member from 1928-1933. He was a member of the board of directors for the Swedish National Association for the Care of Mentally Handicapped Children between 1930-1946, serving as chairman in 1945-1946. He was also a member of the board of Stretered's School Home from 1930-1939 and served as chairman in 1939. He was a member of the Gothenburg Children's Welfare Committee since 1940 and the 40-year school inquiry. He was a member of the board of the Children's Day Association from 1935-1942 and a member of the church council since 1936, as well as a member of the board at the Upper Secondary School from 1940-1941. He wrote articles for school and daily press and was the editor for the Swedish National Elementary School Teachers' History.

Swedish National Association for the Care of Mentally Handicapped Children

structured.description: Viktor Adolf Fredriksson was a Swedish elementary school inspector, born on June 23, 1892 in Nå-runga, Älvsborg County. He was married to Alice Bernsten and had three children. He passed the non-commissioned officer exam at the Göta Artillery Regiment in 1912 and the elementary school teacher exam in 1919. He attended a psychology course at Gothenburg University in 1928, and went on study trips to Denmark, Norway, Germany and Switzerland from 1930-1941. He worked as a collaborator for Goteborgs-Posten from 1913-1919 and was employed as an elementary school teacher from 1919. He became a regular teacher in 1921, a supervisor teacher in 1926 and head teacher in 1933. He served as an elementary school inspector in the Gothenburg region from 1942. He was a press ombudsman for the Swedish National Elementary School Teachers' Association between 1925-1933 and served as a board member from 1928-1933. He was a member of the board of directors for the Swedish National Association for the Care of Mentally Handicapped Children from 1930-1946, serving as chairman in 1945-1946. He was also a member of the board of Stretered's School Home from 1930-1939 and served as chairman in 1939. He was a member of the Gothenburg Children's Welfare Committee since 1940 and the 40-year school inquiry. He was a member of the board of the Children's Day Association from 1935-1942 and a member of the church council since 1936, as well as a member of the board at the Upper Secondary School from 1940-1941. He wrote articles for school and daily press and was the editor for the Swedish National Elementary School Teachers' History.
